History:
History: Samuel K. Doe community is situated on the banks of the Stockton creek and runs along the Somalia Drive. The community also borders Clara Town and Freeport community. It experiences regular flooding during the raining season with periodic fire outbreaks as well as occasional storm. These natural or man- made disasters affect many households every year and sometimes, residents are forced to temporarily relocate inside the community. Many of the community inhabitants are low income dwellers and tenants.
 Samuel K. Doe community was officially named in 1984 after a prolong dispute over the land ownership and the proposed name of the community. The proposed name was 'Sapo community' which members of the Grebo ethnic group resisted on grounds that the name would have given ownership to the Sapo tribe. The community was almost divided as a result of the land dispute between the two tribes, but a small group of concern women took the matter to the then president, H.E. Samuel K. Doe for his intervention. The president ended the dispute by naming the community after himself and asked all parties to live in peace and harmony.
The community has a police station and a community health center which has not been officially opened to the general public. The roads are undergoing rehabilitation and reconstruction and the proposed project is aimed at linking the community to Clara town thus creating easy access to the community and reducing flooding. The settlement is divided into three communities: Success community, Hope community and Cow Factory with local leadership in all. The community has a general leadership in place and a tribal/elder council.

History: Gbalasua is located in the borough of New Kru town, directly opposite the Duala market and behind the st, Mary catholic High school. King Sao Boso set up a trading center in the area that is now called 'Duala' during the colonial period of Liberia and the early years of independence. He was a powerful muslim leader and trader who controlled the north - western part of Liberia at the time.
Few members of the Gola ethnic group settled around the trading center. They were mainly engaged in cassava cultivation. The name 'Gbalasua', means 'cassava farm' in the Gola vernacular. As the new area developed into a complete settlement, it was named 'Gbalasua' because it was already known by many for its production of cassava.
The community has an estimated population of 3400 inhabitants and a total structures of 378. Gbalasua sits on a swampy land and sometimes flooding compels people to temporarily relocate. Many residents in the community are low income dwellers who rely on petty trade for their economic survival. Many of its inhabitants are low income dwellers who rely on petty trading for their economic survival. Trowein Community has an estimated population of 8000 inhabitants with 486 permanent and 26 tempmorary structures.
The area that is now called 'Trowein Community' was formerly known as 'Lagoon East'. The community sits at the mouth of a tributary of the St. Paul River which is widely known as 'Troy'. Trowein is interpreted by the Kru ethnic group as 'Troy Mouth' or the mouth  of the tributary and became a well known name among the Kru people even though Lagoon East was the recognized and official name of the community. Lagoon East was renamed Trowein Community in 1990 during the demarcation of communities in the borough in preparation of the distribution of the Special Emergency Life Food (SELF) rations. History: History: The area where Peace Island now lies was discovered in 2003 by eight women from the Gio ethnic group who were searching for a 'Sandi Bush'(a traditional hide-out where young girls are prepared for womanhood and this includes female genital mutilation). The women quickly informed their friends and relatives as well as IDPs (Internally Displaced Persons) who were living in the unfinished Defense Ministry about the new area. A small group was set up to meet the township commissioner to find out who the owners were, but that meeting did not establish any ownership. Another meeting was held with the minister of land, mines, and energy to ascertain who the owners were and the minister could not also produce the land title. While these engagements were on-going, leadership was set up, land distribution began and people started  building temporary structures for dwelling especially the retired AFL soldiers. Still in their quest to know who owns the land (now Peace Island), the earliest inhabitants met with the Liberian Senate    and its speaker, Hon. George Dweh. The meeting at the Senate still did not establish ownership, but Hon. George Dweh told them to squat there(now Peace Island) until the government gets ready/establishes ownership. The settlement was officially named Peace Island in 2004 and has an estimated population of 30000 inhabitants. It is surrounded by mangrove swamp and sits on top of a hill and also covers 139 acres of land. The settlement has 1780 permanent structures, 558 temporary structures and no public health center.

History: Central New Kru Town is one of the oldest communities in the Borough of New Kru Town dating as far back as 1916. The community began to populate between 1940 and 1950 when the Free port of Monrovia was under construction. And residents living in the Old Kru town area (now called 'Rock Crusher', down waterside, opposite the 'Total Filling Station') were asked to relocate to present - day New Kru town so that the company building the port could crush rocks. Many of them moved to the new area while others chose West Point. The name changed to New Kru Town in the year 1945 because many of its inhabitants were people from 'Old Kru Town'. The name Central New Kru Town was given because it was situated in the center of New Kru Town during the demarcation process.
The community sits sandy soil and experiences periodic fire outbreaks. Most of its work force are casual laborers working in the Free port of Monrovia. Solid waste collection and disposal are challenges the community faces, but water remains an issue. The community has 5 blocks with an estimated population of 6675 inhabitants. 44% of the community 477 structures is temporary.
